prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In the multi-layer network proposed by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021) 125498, each social layer is depicted in Fig. 2. The nodes in the network represent people, and their connections indicate social contact, with varying probabilities of infection based on the edge weight (ranging from 0 to 1). The first layer illustrates home interactions, where groups of different sizes are fully connected internally. These groups, based on the Argentine family size distribution for 2012, do not have external connections, representing individual families as disconnected components. The probability distribution considers family sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members.Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: .A significant portion of the population in any country must engage in economic activities, necessitating interactions with others. Therefore, work is a crucial aspect of social relationships, especially during an epidemic. To model work activity, a generic layer is proposed to connect individuals aged 18 to 59, comprising 60% of the total population in Argentina. Given the diverse jobs and companies, establishing connection rules that accurately reflect reality is challenging. In this study, we consider a typical scenario with random groups ranging in size from 5 to 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected like the "home" layer. An illustration of this layer is displayed in Fig. 2(b) for n = 100. While nodes within a group are fully connected, virus transmission depends on edge weights, as discussed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is essential in most cities but poses a risk for epidemic spread due to high congestion and frequent movement. The third layer proposed represents public transport users, accounting for 50% of the population on average. Groups of varying sizes (10 to 40) are randomly sampled and fully interconnected within each group. This approach considers the average public transport usage in Argentina, which varies based on city size, with around 1.2 hours spent daily.

The nodes are people and do not change across layers, and the weighted connections represent social contact which may lead to infection according to the edge weight (probability value within [0, 1)). The first layer represents home interactions and is composed of a set of groups with varying sizes, which are fully connected internally. These groups have no external connections, i.e., the network starts with disconnected components representing each family. To create each group, we consider the Brazilian family size distribution for 2010 [22], the year with more detailed information on family sizes from 1 up to 14 members. We consider the probability of a family having sizes from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. original_post_context: . A large fraction of the population in any country need to work or practice some kind of economic activity, which means interacting with other people. Thus, work represents one of the most important factors of social relations, which is also very important in an epidemic scenario. To represent the work activity, we propose a generic layer to connect people with ages from 18 to 59 years, i.e., 60% of the total population in the case of Brazil. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using n = 100. Although the nodes of a group are fully connected, the transmission of the virus depends directly on the edge weights, which we discuss in-depth on Section 3.1.1. Collective transports are essential in most cities but are among the most crowded environments and play an important role in an epidemic scenario due to the possibility of geographical spread, as vehicles are constantly moving around. The third layer we propose represents these public transports that include people who do not possess or use a personal vehicle. In Brazil the number of people using public transport depends on the size of the city, with 64.98% in the capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], with an average use of around 1.2 h a day.1 Here we consider the average of the population between the two cases (50%), randomly sampled, to participate in the ''transports'' layer. Random groups are created with sizes between [10, 40], uniformly sampled, and the nodes within each group are fully connected. prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (2021) introduced a multi-layer network model in Physica A 564 to simulate social interactions that may lead to infection. The nodes in the network represent individuals, with each layer representing a different social context. The first layer depicts home interactions, with groups of varying sizes that are internally fully connected. Each family is represented as a disconnected component, with family sizes based on the Peruvian family size distribution for 2010. The probability of a family having sizes from 1 to 10 members is considered, ensuring that each family has at least one adult. The structure of this layer is illustrated in Fig. 2(a) for a population of 100 individuals. Additionally, a layer representing work interactions was proposed to connect individuals aged 18 to 59 years, accounting for 60% of the total population in Peru. Work interactions are crucial in modeling social relations, especially in an epidemic scenario.There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: .The virus transmission within a group's nodes depends on edge weights, as discussed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation in cities is a key factor in epidemic scenarios due to high population density and movement. Our proposed third layer focuses on these transports, which cater to those without personal vehicles. In Peru, around 50% of the population use public transport, with varying numbers depending on city size. We consider an average participation rate of 50% in our analysis. Random groups are formed, with sizes ranging from 10 to 40, and fully connected nodes within each group. This approach allows for a realistic representation of public transport dynamics.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In the study conducted by eiva et al. (2021), the researchers examined the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospitalizations. The simulation began with a social network with different layers and initial infection probabilities. The infection started at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread in daily iterations over 300 days. In an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the start, the initial infection probability was set to β < 1 to mimic natural social distancing practices. This included reducing physical contact and taking precautions to prevent the spread of the virus. The researchers observed that this initial value of β better reflected the Argentinian pandemic. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was imposed to simulate the measures implemented by most Argentinian states on March 24. During this quarantine, certain layers, such as religious activities and schools, were removed, and contacts in transportation and work were reduced to 30% of their initial value (β = 0.09). Essential services and activities that continued with precautions were maintained. The researchers analyzed the impact of the β parameter on the epidemic curve and found that higher infection rates led to faster disease spread but also quicker natural immunization of recovered individuals.4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinian epidemic (up to May 17) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model demonstrates a notable overall similarity within its standard deviation. The recent increase in diagnosed cases in Argentina may be due to an increase in testing or a decrease in isolation levels in the country (consistently below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. In our analysis, we assumed a fixed isolation level similar to the early days after government decrees in Argentina, but data indicates that these levels are constantly changing. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may be higher than those reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). Regarding daily death tolls, the average numbers predicted by the model are higher than official figures, likely due to underdetection rates and limited testing. An examination of death numbers in Argentina from January 1 to April 30 reveals a significant increase after February 26, the date of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina, suggesting that the actual death toll may be considerably higher than reported. Moving forward, we consider four potential actions to take after 90 days (May 26): maintain current isolation levels, return to normal activities, resume only work activities, or increase isolation by halting work and transport activities.
original_pre_context: eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 the effects of different actions on the overall epidemic picture, such as the increase and reduction of cases, deaths, and occupied beds in hospitals. The social network starts with all its layers and the original infection probabilities. The infection begins at a node with the closest degree to the average network degree and propagates at iterations of 1 day (up to 300 days). We consider an optimistic scenario in which people are aware of the virus since the beginning, thus the initial infection probability is β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e., β = 0.09. The remaining activities on these layers represent services that could not be stopped, such as essential services, activities that are kept taking higher precautionary measures and disrespecting the quarantine. Under this scenario, we first analyze how the β parameter impacts the overall epidemic shape. Fig. 4(a) shows results for 4 β values in function of daily new cases and deaths, iterating from up to 300 days after the first infection. As higher the infection rates, faster is the disease spreading and the final number of cases and deaths. On the other hand, the epidemic ends faster due to natural immunization of recovered nodes. 4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Brazilian epidemic (up to May 18) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
original_post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model achieves a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be related to the increase in Brazil's tests. Or yet, the constant decrease of isolation levels in the country (below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. We considered here a fixed isolation level around what was observed in the first days after the government decrees in Brazil. Still, data from the same reference show that these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths for the remaining simulation may be higher than the reported on this paper (see the ''keep isolation'' scenario in the next section). Concerning the daily death toll, the average number of the proposed models is higher than that of the official numbers. This is somehow expected, considering that the underdetection rates may be higher in contrast to the fewer number of tests being performed. To better understand this, we analyzed the number of death in Brazil from January 1 to April 30, comparing cases between 2019 and 2020; the results are shown in Fig. 5. It is possible to observe a clear increasing pattern after February 26, which is the day of the first officially confirmed case of COVID-19 in Brazil, indicating that the real death toll may be significantly higher than the official numbers. 4.2. Future actions and its impacts After the initial epidemic phase, we consider four possible actions that can be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Do nothing more, maintaining the current isolation levels; b) Stop isolation, returning activities to normal (initial network layers and weights); c) Return only work activities, restoring the initial probability of the layer; or d) Increase isolation, stopping the remaining activities in work and transport

Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 shows the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios 90 days after the onset of the pandemic on May 26th: (a) Maintaining current isolation measures (no schools or religious gatherings, reduced work and public transport), (b) Ending isolation (returning to normal with schools, religious gatherings, work, and public transport), or (c) Increasing isolation (halt work and public transport). Due to limitations in testing capacity, only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed, either due to a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus exceeding testing capabilities.Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).After 27 days since the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented, halting schools and religious activities while work and transportation continued at 30% capacity through a reduction in the transmission rate. After 90 days, four options were considered: maintaining current levels of isolation, increasing isolation, fully ending isolation and returning to normal activities, or only returning work activities. It was found that maintaining current isolation levels would lead to prolonged spread with a peak expected around June 5, resulting in approximately 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily deaths, totaling 946,830 diagnosed cases (with up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths by the end of the year. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity by June 11, but with efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper patient management, the situation can potentially be controlled. However, this optimistic outlook assumes a level of social isolation above 50%, as seen at the beginning of the Argentinian quarantine. Social isolation levels in Argentina are currently at 12%.

After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). In this scenario, hospitals may exceed its maximum capacity around June 11. However, the efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper logistic management of patients may still keep the situation under control. However, this is a very optimistic assumption, considering that our definition of ''keep isolation'' considers social isolation above 50% as registered at the beginning of the Brazilian quarantine [43]. However, by effectively adding ICU beds and managing patient logistics, the situation can still be controlled. author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers analyzed three scenarios after 90 days of the COVID-19 pandemic. These scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Testing was limited due to a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus. The study assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases continued to spread the virus unknowingly. The researchers also made optimistic assumptions about infected individuals isolating themselves at home if they had mild symptoms, and severe or critical cases being hospitalized and isolated from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. This model is utilized in both Scenarios 1 and 3 to showcase the infection rate resulting from mandatory mask-wearing. To account for the gradual decrease in compliance with universal masking, Equation (9) is adjusted to Equation (10). Epidemiological Parameters To conduct our analysis in the Hong Kong context, we estimate the epidemiological parameters described in the earlier sections for Hong Kong's context: • • • •
post_context: : According to the position statement released by the National Centre of Disease Control Hong Kong [21], a person remains infectious for up to 11 days after first contracting COVID-19.With a parameter value of δ = 1/5, it is known that the SARS-CoV2 virus typically has an incubation period of around 5 days. Additionally, with α = 0.000064, the fatality rate is determined as the percentage of deaths among all previously infected individuals. In the context of Hong Kong during this study, there were 26 deaths and a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. Given the variability and unpredictability of this number among different demographics, an average was set at 9 days for analysis purposes. Moving on to the results and discussion section, the SEIR models were applied to various scenarios to examine the impact of delays in enforcing mask wearing. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance and no time-limited immunity, different levels of delay in mask enforcement were simulated, including immediate enforcement, a 50-day delay, a 100-day delay, and no enforcement at all. The results show that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a decrease in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the time taken to reach this maximum value. This trend is illustrated by the rightward shift of the peak of the Infected compartment curve and a lower maximum value. The infected number rises until it reaches a global maximum before declining, as predicted by compartmental models.

Results and Discussion 6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing Upon applying the SEIR models to the 3 scenarios described in the above sections, we are able to obtain Maximum Infected Values by simulating different values of delay in mask enforcement. Considering the most basic case of Scenario 1; where there is complete compliance throughout the duration of mask enforcement, and the absence of time-limited immunity, Figure 3 shows the cases where mask wearing were to be enforced (a) on the day the first case of COVID-19 was detected in Singapore; (b) after a 50 days delay; (c) after a 100 days delay; and (d) not enforced at all. From Figure 3, it can be deduced that earlier enforcement of mask wearing both reduces the Maximum Infected Value as well as increases the number of days taken to reach the Maximum Infected Value. This is reflected by right-ward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment, as well as a lower maxima value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. Additionally, due to the small number of COVID-19 deaths in Malaysia, calculating an average using this limited data would be inaccurate. Therefore, for analysis purposes, we have set it at 9 days.

6. Results and Discussion

6.1. Delay Dynamics of Compulsory Mask Wearing

By applying SEIR models to the scenarios discussed earlier, we were able to determine Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, with complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, we compared cases where mask wearing was enforced on different timelines: (a) upon detection of the first COVID-19 case in Malaysia, (b) after a 50-day delay, (c) after a 100-day delay, and (d) not enforced at all.

Analysis from Figure 3 indicates that earlier enforcement of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also delays reaching this point. The infected number peaks and then decreases, as expected from compartmental models. For example, with 0 days of delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is around 10.453% on day 291. With a 50-day delay, it is around 10.479% on day 195. However, with a 100-day delay, the maximum infected value significantly increases to approximately 27.474% on day 103, similar to the case where no public masking is enforced.

original_post_context: [25]. To investigate the impact of delay in public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers due to the B117 variant, we modelled a hypothetical scenario. In this scenario, the first case of COVID-19 detected in Singapore is of the B117 variant. We ran our simulation of the 3 scenarios described in the preceding sections with a new value of R0 reflecting that of B117. The resulting plots are shown in Figure 6 and 7. Figure 6. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with full compliance and Scenario 3: SEIRS with time-limited immunity for the B117 variant case. Figure 7. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with gradual noncompliance for the B117 variant case. 6.3. Related Studies Juxtaposing our study against other similar studies that implement mathematical modelling on 'what-if' scenario based analysis, Eikenberry et al. [3] implemented a compartmentalized models for their simulations, and concluded that if the population remains unmasked until mask enforcement after some discrete delay, and that the level of adoption is fixed, the delay initially had little impact on the hospitalized fraction or deaths, but states that a 'point of no return' can be crossed. While this study yields similar results to ours, it is contextualised in the US states of New York and Washington, whilst ours was conducted in the context of Singapore. Given the differences in epidemiological parameters, size and characteristics of these cities and Singapore, our study adds value in being a more accurate representation of smaller city states. Furthermore, this study did not take into consideration newer, more infectious strains of the virus such as the B117 variant and time-limited immunity, which we have considered in our study.

Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity. A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures. post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23). Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions imposed by Hubei on infection rates in Beijing is similar to increasing quarantine measures by a significant amount. Evaluating the effectiveness and duration of these costly interventions by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infections is crucial. Under strict measures, it is projected that the outbreak will peak within two weeks, with a considerable reduction in cases. Implementing travel restrictions can result in a significant decrease in infected individuals in Beijing. Overall, it is important to assess how these interventions can impact the management and control of coronavirus infections.

Introduction Coronaviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses belonging to the family of Coronaviridae [1]. They cause generally mild respiratory infections, even though they are occasionally lethal. Since their discovery and first characterization in 1965 [2], three major, large-scale outbreaks have occurred, caused by emerging, highly pathogenic coronaviruses, namely, the "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome" (SARS) outbreak in 2003 in mainland China [3], the "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome" (MERS) outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia [4,5] and the MERS outbreak in 2015 in South J. post_context:
.As of January 10, 2020, two patients had recovered and were discharged from the hospital, resulting in R(0) = 2, with 739 individuals being quarantined, leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set H(0) = 1 to correspond with the confirmed case reported on January 10, 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, giving λ = 1/14. The WHO states that the incubation period for 2019-nCoV is approximately 7 days, making σ = 1/7.

Regarding the likelihood-based estimates, analysis of Rc during the Hubei outbreak yielded an average value of 6.39 with a mean and variance of generation time at 6 and 2 days based on a revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number calculated through likelihood-based estimation ranges from 1.66 to 10, illustrating sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals, as shown in Table 2. Analysis of another revised data series (dataRev2) produced an average value of 6.32 with a mean and variance of generation time at 6 and 2 days. The estimates of Rc from both time series align well, allowing for the use of either dataRev1 or dataRev2 to fit the proposed transmission model. This study selects dataRev1 as the comparison reference for verifying and validating our model-based estimation, thus utilizing this dataset for subsequent analysis in the manuscript.

original_post_context: . As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set H(0) = 1, corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, thus λ = 1/14. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence σ = 1/7. 3. Results 3.1. Likelihood-Based Estimates Likelihood-based estimation of Rc during the outbreak in Wuhan gives a mean value of 6.39 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days on the basis of a revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number based on likelihood-based estimation ranges from 1.66 to 10 and it follows from Table 2 that Rc is sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals. Fitting to the other revised data series (dataRev2) gives a mean value of 6.32 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days. Note that the estimates of Rc based on the two time series agree well, and consequently, both revised data series can be used to fit the proposed dynamics transmission model. In this study, we chose the estimations based on dataRev1 as the comparison reference to verify and validate our model-based estimation. Thus, in the following sections of the manuscript, we will use the revised dataset (dataRev1) to fit the proposed model.

H(0) was set to 1, representing the first confirmed case reported on 10 January 2020, and individuals were quarantined for 14 days, resulting in λ = 1/14. The WHO states that the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is approximately 7 days, leading to σ = 1/7. 

Likelihood-based estimation of Rc in Hubei during the outbreak indicates a mean value of 6.39 and mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days based on a revised dataset (dataRev1). The reproduction number ranges from 1.66 to 10 and is sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals. Another revised dataset (dataRev2) shows a mean value of 6.32 for Rc with the same generation time statistics. Both revised datasets align well in Rc estimates, allowing for the fitting of the proposed transmission model. DataRev1 was chosen as the comparison reference for model validation in this study, with subsequent sections utilizing this dataset.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Likelihood-Based Estimation Method for Basic Reproduction Number 

In our study, we utilized the likelihood-based method developed by White and Pagano [23], incorporating information on the generation interval. The formula used for this estimation is given by L(Rc, p|N) = T∏ t=1 exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1), where φt = Rc ∑j=1 pjNt− j. The maximum value for the serial interval, denoted as k, was set to 6. N represents the total case numbers on each day j, with T being the final observation day. The probability function for the generation interval on each day j is represented by pj. We assumed a gamma distribution for the generation interval with mean E and variance V. To account for the uncertainty in the generation interval of the 2019-nCoV, we varied the mean E value between 2 and 8 days.

The table below presents the estimation results for the basic reproduction number for 2019-nCoV in Wenzhou, China, under different mean E values and variance V values.

As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set H(0) = 1, corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, thus
post_context: .According to the World Health Organization (WHO), the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is approximately 7 days, resulting in a σ value of 1/7. Likelihood-based estimates of the reproduction number (Rc) in Wenzhou during the outbreak suggest a mean value of 6.39 with a mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days based on a revised data series (dataRev1). The range of Rc based on likelihood-based estimation is between 1.66 and 10, highlighting the sensitivity of Rc to changes in mean generation intervals. Another analysis using a different revised data series (dataRev2) shows a mean Rc value of 6.32 with a mean and variance of generation time also at 6 and 2 days. The estimates of Rc from both time series are in agreement, allowing both dataRev1 and dataRev2 to be used to fit the proposed transmission model. For this study, dataRev1 is chosen as the comparison reference to validate our model-based estimation, and this dataset will be used in the following sections of the research.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
In this study, we utilized the likelihood-based method developed by White and Pagano to estimate the basic reproduction number (R0) for the 2019-nCoV outbreak in Hubei, China. The formula used in our analysis is L(Rc, p|N) = T∏ t=1 exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1), where φt represents the expected number of secondary cases generated by a primary case on day t. We considered a gamma distribution for the generation interval with mean E and variance V. To account for uncertainty in the generation interval, we explored different mean values ranging from 2 to 8 days. The estimated values for R0 based on various E and V combinations are presented in Table 2. For simulations, we assumed the initial susceptible population in Hubei to be approximately 11,081,000 individuals.

As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set H(0) = 1, corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, thus λ = 1/14. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence
post_context:
.3.

Results 3.1. Likelihood-Based Estimates
The estimation of the reproduction number (Rc) during the Hubei outbreak using likelihood-based methods yielded a mean value of 6.39 with a mean and variance of the generation time at 6 and 2 days based on a revised dataset (dataRev1). The range of Rc estimates from likelihood-based methods was found to be between 1.66 and 10, and it was observed that Rc is sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals as shown in Table 2. Analysis of a different revised dataset (dataRev2) produced a mean value of 6.32 with a mean and variance of generation time at 6 and 2 days. It is important to note that estimates of Rc based on both datasets were consistent, allowing for the utilization of either dataset for fitting the proposed transmission model. For comparison and validation purposes, the estimations from dataRev1 were selected as the reference for verifying our model-based estimates. Therefore, the following sections of the manuscript will utilize the revised dataset (dataRev1) for model fitting.

Furthermore, we noted that more recently published studies based on datasets during periods comparable with ours reported similar findings in terms of a high basic reproduction number (for instance, Reference [29], where authors, using an exponential growth method, computed a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16), assuming no changes in reporting rate and with a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days). Some crucial information may be missing, and the quality, accuracy and reliability of data improves over time. In these situations, estimations are highly dependent on the specific datasets utilized and revising/updating such datasets could influence the results. Estimations heavily rely on the datasets used, and updating them could impact results. Clinical parameters can be derived from sero-epidemiological surveys, while the potential of transmission from asymptomatic cases was only recently acknowledged. The high reproduction number suggests a serious epidemic is possible without swift public health interventions, especially during periods of increased social contact. The accuracy of likelihood function estimation is influenced by the serial interval, with the incubation period for Chongqing coronavirus pneumonia patients ranging from 2 to 15 days according to recent reports. We then assume that the serial interval follows the gamma distribution with varying mean and variance, which allows us to examine the influence on the reproduction number. With the distribution of serial interval with mean 6 days and variance 2 days, the likelihood-based estimation of the reproduction number is consistent with the model-based estimation. It shows that longer serial intervals induce greater reproduction numbers, and hence, more new infections, which further confirms that the epidemic may be more serious than what has been reported until now [15]. The threshold values of contact rate and quarantine rate necessary to prevent an outbreak are illustrated in the R_c = 1 contour plot. This high threshold rate of quarantine places significant demands on the city's public health infrastructure and citizens' adherence to protective measures such as reducing contacts, separation, and quarantine restrictions. Achieving this level of quarantine and contact reduction is challenging, especially when dealing with imported cases and implementing travel restrictions. Strict travel restrictions to Chongqing are costly and resource-intensive, posing a challenge for decision-makers and the city's resilience. Despite these efforts, such measures may only delay the transmission of the disease.

author: enrique
pre_context: Counties in Ohio with greater air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of infection compared to neighboring counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. The severity of the COVID-19 epidemic in these counties was not only influenced by population distribution but also by spatial attributes such as transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Ohio were concentrated in just five counties (Mahoning, Fairview, Luke, Birmingham, and Mountain Top), with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs with airports that see over 10,000,000 passengers annually. The influx of travelers through these airports can introduce imported infections, leading to accelerated local transmission of the virus and faster spread within these areas. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . In contrast, only 7% of the total ICU beds in the state are located in the rural and less connected counties, equating to 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite this disparity in critical healthcare capacity, our analysis shows that the lower transmission rates in these areas prevented critical care saturation. Maintaining non-pharmaceutical interventions from mid-March to early May would result in only 27% of maximum critical care capacity being reached in the state, with certain counties reaching over 50% capacity. If interventions were eased by 50%, an estimated 61% of the state's critical care capacity would be reached within eight weeks, particularly impacting areas with higher transmission rates. Counties with faster spread experienced a faster saturation of critical care, while rural counties saw slower infection spread.

pre_context: The adjusted model indicated that the differences in COVID-19 severity among counties in Michigan were influenced not only by population distribution but also by factors such as transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were found in five counties, with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties, including Cuyahoga, Franklin, Lucas, Montgomery, and Summit, have high population density and serve as major air hubs. Airports in these counties see over 10 million passengers annually, potentially bringing in imported infections and accelerating local transmission. In contrast, infection rates were much lower in rural and less connected counties in Michigan. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Michigan, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a rate of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a
post_context: . Despite variations in healthcare capacity across different regions of the state, our analysis shows that the lower transmission rates in rural and less connected counties helped prevent overwhelming the critical care system in those areas. Maintaining non-pharmaceutical interventions after early May would result in only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity being reached, with a few counties approaching 50%. However, easing interventions by 50% could lead to 61% of the state's critical care capacity being reached within eight weeks. Regions with higher disease transmission would reach capacity faster, particularly Group 1 counties, despite having higher initial capacity. On the other hand, rural counties in Group 4 experienced slower infection spread, which helped prevent their critical care system from being overwhelmed.

author: enrique
pre_context: The projection for the end of 2021 suggests that approximately 680,000 people will have been infected with COVID-19 in Ontario, with half of them showing no symptoms. The sharpest increase in cumulative infections occurred in December 2021 and March 2022, coinciding with peaks in new case counts. By the end of the year, it is expected that 71% of the population in Ontario will have received at least one dose of the vaccine, with 57% fully vaccinated. Of the projected 11,000 COVID-related deaths by the end of 2021, 36% are from the wild type, 47% from Alpha, and 17% from Delta variants. These predictions closely align with the reported data for Ontario. The population dynamics indicated in the figures show a significant decrease in the number of susceptible individuals starting from December 2021, largely due to the vaccine rollout. By June 2022, only 37% of the population will still be susceptible, with most having received at least one dose of the vaccine. The number of active infections peaked at the end of 2021, followed by an even higher peak in the spring, driven by the wild type and Alpha variants. The Alpha-driven wave, accounting for 0.7% of the population, diminishes as vaccination efforts intensify. The infections are roughly split equally between asymptomatic and symptomatic cases, with the majority of cases occurring in unvaccinated individuals. As the infections spread, the number of recovered individuals also rises, reaching 7% of the population by the end of 2021. These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. To identify the strongest determinants of the pandemic severity, we assess the sensitivity of model predictions to variations in key model parameters. post_context: (i.e., infectivity β's halved) for simplicity. Vaccination will commence on April 1, 2020, in this one-year simulation, with Pfizer having a baseline dosing interval of 4 weeks and AstraZeneca 8 weeks. Various parameters will be altered, such as clinical virus features, provincial policies, and pharmaceutical interventions. Clinical virus features, including infectivity, asymptomatic fraction, infectivity ratio, mortality rate, and recovery rates, will be adjusted. The number of infections directly correlates with infectivity, asymptomatic fraction, infectivity ratio, and recovery rate, all of which significantly impact the spread of the disease.

Vaccination begins on April 1 2020 (not the end of 2020, for this simplified one-year simulation), with baseline dosing interval taken to be 4 weeks for Pfizer and 8 weeks for AstraZeneca (dosing interval is one of the parameters varied)17. Parameters that are varied include those that describe the clinical features of the viruses as well as provincial policy and pharmaceutical intervention. Clinical features of the viruses that were considered include its infectivity (βW), the fraction of infections that are asymptomatic (σW), the infectivity ratio between asymptomatic and symptomatic individuals (αW), mortality rate (μW), and recovery rates (γWA and γWI, varied simultaneously). Recall the baseline assumption that asymptomatic individuals are assumed to be more active and 3 times more likely to spread the disease than symptomatic ones (αW = 3). post_context: affects the number of infected individuals who are alive and can participate in the spread of the disease.Due to the significant impact of health care infrastructure on COVID-19 mortality rates, we made adjustments to the parameter μW I by 50%. These changes were immediately reflected in the number of deaths, although the mortality rate had a relatively small effect on the overall infected population, with less than 5% of those infected dying. Various provincial policies and pharmaceutical interventions were considered, including non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI), vaccination rates, dosing intervals, and vaccine escape rates. NPI had a large impact on model predictions, while vaccination rates also played a significant role in controlling the spread of the disease. Dosing interval and vaccine escape rate had smaller effects and were varied by 50% due to the variability within the population. Results indicated that effective vaccine deployment was crucial in combating the pandemic, and prioritizing the first dose in case of limited vaccine supply could be beneficial. A sensitivity analysis was conducted using a full model representing all three variants, with key parameters increased to observe their effects on infections and deaths. The analysis highlighted the importance of vaccination rates in controlling the pandemic.

Because dosing interval can vary greatly within the population, and because vaccine escape rate is not sufficiently well characterized, these two parameters were varied by 50%. The vaccine-related results suggest that among these three factors, an effective vaccine deployment (captured in ω1) is the key in combating a pandemic, and success may be achieved even by means of a less-than-ideal vaccine with higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Since the predicted numbers of infections and deaths are substantially more sensitive to variations in ω1 than ω2, if vaccine supply is limited, prioritizing the first dose by lengthening the dosing interval would be advisable, as was done in Canada. author: chunwei
pre_context: Figure 2 displays data on new infections, cumulative infections, vaccination rates, and cumulative deaths for various viruses from January 1, 2021, to December 31, 2021. Small fluctuations in these parameters can have significant impacts on infection and mortality rates, as shown in Fig. 4. The COVID-19 mortality rate determines the number of infected individuals who remain alive and can contribute to disease transmission. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS-CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ),
post_context: delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2, PZ, and ω2, AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). λ and ω1 were adjusted by 5%. As NPI are influenced by scaling βW directly, they have a significant impact on model predictions (Fig. 4). The vaccination rate also plays a role in the spread of the disease, albeit to a lesser extent. On the other hand, the dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βWV) have smaller effects. Due to the variability of dosing intervals within the population and the lack of characterization of the vaccine escape rate, these two parameters were adjusted by 50%. The results related to vaccines indicate that among these factors, an effective vaccine deployment is crucial in fighting a pandemic, and success can still be achieved with a less-than-ideal vaccine that has a higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Prioritizing the first dose by extending the dosing interval, as seen in Canada, would be wise if vaccine supply is limited. In a secondary analysis, the full model encompassing all three variants was considered using baseline parameter values. Key model parameters were increased to evaluate their impact on infections and deaths associated with each variant. In addition to the parameters mentioned earlier, factors mediating VOC interactions were also taken into account, such as βXR (rate of infection for individuals with partial immunity from a different variant) and ηR (rate of immunity loss due to infection). Parameters for individual variants were varied separately in simulations, with specific increases in βX, σX, αX, γX, and ω1 by 5%, λ by 10%, and μI, βXR by 4 times to assess the effects on V, and ω2 by 50%.

pre_context: Figure 2 illustrates the number of new infections for various viruses, depicted as 7-day averages from January 1, 2022, to December 31, 2021. The graph also shows the cumulative total of asymptomatic and symptomatic infections, the percentage of the population vaccinated with one or both doses, and the cumulative deaths from each virus. Even small fluctuations (5%) in these factors can lead to significantly higher changes in infection rates and fatalities, as seen in Figure 4. The mortality rate of COVID-19 impacts the number of infected individuals who remain alive and can contribute to the spread of the illness. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ), vaccination rate (ω1), delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2,PZ and ω2,AZ, varied simultaneously), and
post_context: λ and ω1 are varied by 5%. Scaling NPI by directly adjusting βW has a significant impact on model predictions, as shown in Figure 4, while vaccination rates also play a role in disease spread. The impact of dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) is smaller. Due to the variability of dosing intervals within the population and lack of characterization of vaccine escape rates, these parameters were adjusted by 50%. The results indicate that effective vaccine deployment (represented by ω1) is crucial in combating a pandemic, suggesting that even a less-than-ideal vaccine with a higher escape rate can be successful. Prioritizing the first dose by extending the dosing interval may be advisable in situations of limited vaccine supply, as seen in Canada. A sensitivity analysis using the full model involving all three variants showed that certain key parameters, including those mediating interactions between variants, have a notable impact on the number of infections and deaths. Simulations were conducted by varying parameter values for individual variants separately. Specifically, parameters such as βX, σX, αX, γX, and ω1 were increased by specified percentages, while others like λ and μI were adjusted to assess their effects. βX R was increased by four folds to evaluate its impact on VOC interactions.

Small variations in these four parameters (5%) result in changes in the number of infections and deaths that are an order of magnitude larger; see Fig. 4. COVID-19 mortality rate μW I affects the number of infected individuals who are alive and can participate in the spread of the disease. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ), vaccination rate (ω1), delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2,PZ and ω2,AZ, varied simultaneously), and
original_post_context: λ and ω1 are varied by 5%. Since NPI are modelled by scaling βW directly, they have large effects on model predictions (Fig. 4). Vaccination rate has lesser but still significant effects on the spread of the disease. The effects of dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) are much smaller. Because dosing interval can vary greatly within the population, and because vaccine escape rate is not sufficiently well characterized, these two parameters were varied by 50%. The vaccine-related results suggest that among these three factors, an effective vaccine deployment (captured in ω1) is the key in combating a pandemic, and success may be achieved even by means of a less-than-ideal vaccine with higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Since the predicted numbers of infections and deaths are substantially more sensitive to variations in ω1 than ω2, if vaccine supply is limited, prioritizing the first dose by lengthening the dosing interval would be advisable, as was done in Canada. In a second sensitivity analysis, we considered the full model that represents all three variants, using the baseline parameter values (Table S1). Key model parameters were increased to determine the effects on the number of infections and deaths associated with each variant. In addition to parameters considered in the above analysis, we also considered two parameters that mediate VOC interactions: βX R, rate of infection of individuals with partial immunity from having recovered from a different variant, and ηR, rate of loss of immunity due to infection. Some of these parameters have distinct values for each of the variants. Simulations were conducted by varying each of the parameter values for individual variants separately. author: enrique
pre_context: Figure 5 illustrates the impact of changes in model parameters on total infections and deaths during a two-year simulation involving the dynamics of different variants. The parameters are individually adjusted for the wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants. The analysis includes variations in virus infectivity, rate of infection from individuals with a different variant, ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic infections, and other factors. The baseline model assumes a vaccine distribution similar to that in Ontario, with a higher percentage of Pfizer vaccines. The potential effects of a larger proportion of AstraZeneca vaccines, as seen in the UK, are also considered. It is noted that the Pfizer vaccine provides better protection against all COVID variants, particularly Delta, compared to AstraZeneca. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By December 31, 2021, the model predicts
post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a). The number of Delta infections and deaths is expected to rise significantly by December 31, 2021, reaching 62 K and 882, respectively, compared to the initial values of 39 K and 689. If the vaccination rate in the province is lower, with only 67% of the population vaccinated with one dose by September 1, 2021, compared to the initial rate of 74%, the number of infections and deaths due to Delta variant could increase by 75% by March 2022. Ontario started gradually reopening in mid-June 2021, with in-person classes scheduled to resume in September. It is assumed that the NPI still in place will reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%, but this may be overly optimistic as pandemic fatigue and desire for interaction increase. Considering potential outbreaks in schools, a scenario with less strict NPI from fall 2021 (September 1, 2021) is also considered, with an increased value of λ from the baseline of 0.4.

If the provincial vaccination rate were lower, such that by September 1 2021 only 67% of the population are vaccinated with at least one dose, compared to the baseline vaccinated percentage of 74% (Fig. 7c), the total number of Delta infections and deaths would increase by 75% by the end of March 2022; see Fig. 7b,d. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In comparison with the results shown in Figure 2, we have observed higher projected cumulative confirmed cases and a delayed peak time. In a previous study by Tang et al. (2020), we estimated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which is higher than values reported in other studies. For example, the WHO estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, while Li et al. (2020) calculated a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9). Various mathematical models have reported reproduction numbers ranging from 1.3 to 4.7. Two studies in the literature have highlighted the underestimation of coronavirus cases, with Zhao et al. (2020) and Read et al. (2020) both discussing this issue. Zhao et al. (2020) quantitatively assessed under-reporting of coronavirus cases and estimated 469 underreported cases (95% CI 403e540), leading to a computed basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). In a previous version of this investigation, released on the bioRxiv pre-print server, the reproduction number was found to range from 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) to 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10).The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an
post_context: (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Hubei, China, there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections.The basic reproduction number was calculated to be 3.11 (95% CI 2.39-4.13), indicating that blocking at least 58-76% of transmissions is necessary to halt the outbreak. Several models have been developed to analyze the impact of international travel on the spread of the virus, including those by Imai et al. (2020), Kucharski et al. (2020), and Wu et al. (2020). Imai et al. (2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5-3.5), with variations from 1.7 to 4.2 depending on different scenarios and levels of zoonotic exposure. The reproduction number also fluctuated between 1.3 and 4.3 based on various estimates of generation time. Figure 2 illustrates the predictions and impact of control measures on infection, assuming that parameters from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 remain constant. These measures include decreasing the minimum contact rate after January 29th, 2020, and adjusting the susceptible population size as of that date.

Discussion In our previous article (Tang et al., 2020), we had estimated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which represents a higher value than those so far computed. For instance, the WHO has estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, Li and colleagues (Li et al., 2020) have computed a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9), while in several other mathematical models which have been so far devised and released as pre-prints or undergone peer-review and published, the reproduction number varies from 1.3 to 4.7. Within the existing literature, two studies estimated under-estimation of coronavirus cases: the investigations by Zhao and collaborators (Zhao et al., 2020) and by Read et al. (Read, Bridgen, Cummings, Ho, & Jewell, 2020). Specifically, Zhao and coworkers (Zhao et al., 2020) have assessed from a quantitative standpoint the under-reporting rate of coronavirus cases, modeling the epidemic growth curve using the exponential growing Poisson process. Authors computed the number of under-reported coronavirus cases to be 469 (95% CI 403e540). Based on this estimate, the basic reproduction number was found to be 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). In a previous version of the investigation, released in the bioRxiv pre-print server, the reproduction number was computed to oscillate between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10). The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an
original_post_context: (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Wuhan there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. The basic reproduction number was computed to be 3.11 (95% CI 2.39e4.13). In terms of public health implications, in order to stop the outbreak, at least 58e76% of transmissions should be blocked. There are three further models incorporating data from international travels: the models of Imai and coauthors (Imai et al., 2020), of Kucharski et al. (Kucharski et al., 2020) and of Wu and collaborators (Wu, Leung, & Leung, 2020). In particular, Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5e3.5). Depending on the different scenarios and levels of zoonotic exposure, the reproduction number was found to vary from 1.7 to 2.6 to 1.9e4.2. Depending on the different estimates of generation time, the reproduction number oscillated from 1.3 to 2.7 to 1.7e4.3. Based Fig. 2. Predictions and effect of control measures on infection based on assumption that parameters obtained from fitting the data from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 (and hence the interventions) remain unchanged. (AeB) Decreasing the minimum contact rate after January 29th, 2020; (CeD) Decreasing/increasing the susceptible population size as of January 29th, 2020.

author: enrique
pre_context: The reproduction number of the coronavirus, as estimated in this study, is 6.47 (95% CI 5.71-7.23), which is higher than previous calculations. Other estimates from organizations like WHO and studies by Li et al. and various mathematical models have reported values ranging from 1.4 to 4.7. Some studies, like those by Zhao et al. and Read et al., have suggested that there may be an underestimation of coronavirus cases. Zhao et al. used a quantitative approach to estimate that there may be 469 (95% CI 403-540) underreported cases, leading to a calculated reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49-2.63). Earlier versions of their study suggested a range of 3.30 (95% CI 2.73-3.96) to 5.47 (95% CI 4.16-7.10) for the reproduction number. The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-fold to 2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an ascertainment rate of 5.0% (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Beijing there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and
post_context: . The basic reproduction number was calculated to be 3.11 (95% CI 2.39-4.13), indicating that in order to halt the outbreak, 58-76% of transmissions need to be prevented. Three additional models incorporating data from international travel have been developed: one by Imai and colleagues (Imai et al., 2020), another by Kucharski et al. (Kucharski et al., 2020), and a third by Wu and collaborators (Wu, Leung, & Leung, 2020). Specifically, Imai et al. (2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5-3.5), which varied from 1.7 to 2.6 to 1.9-4.2 depending on scenarios and levels of zoonotic exposure. The reproduction number fluctuated between 1.3 to 2.7 to 1.7-4.3 based on different estimates of generation time. Predictions and the impact of control measures on infection were based on the assumption that parameters derived from data up to January 29th, 2020, and interventions, remained constant. This involved decreasing the minimum contact rate post January 29th, 2020 and adjusting the susceptible population size as of January 29th, 2020.

The reproduction number ranged from 1.6 to 2.9, with an estimated value of 2.0 assuming the novel virus would result in more mild-to-moderate cases compared to SARS. Public health interventions blocking over 60% of transmission were deemed effective in controlling the coronavirus outbreak based on research by Imai and Yu. Yu calculated a basic reproduction number of 3.5 and suggested a quarantine rate of over 90% for effective control. Kucharski and colleagues utilized a stochastic SEIR model with time-varying reproduction numbers, providing real-time estimates using various datasets and the Poisson probability calculation to address data reliability concerns.Transmission was modeled as a random process, fluctuating and varying over the time. Similar to the model of Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020), the risk of transmission and the risk of causing a large outbreak were modeled based on a negative binomial offspring distribution, with incubation and infectious period being Erlang distributed. Median reproduction number was found to oscillate between 1.6 and 2.9 before the introduction and implementation of travel restriction. The basic reproduction number was calculated to be 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), decreasing to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99e2.18) by January 22nd, 2020. The outbreak was expected to decrease significantly within 77 days (95% CI 75e80) from its onset. It was also discovered that a one-day decrease in the time from illness onset to isolation could lower the peak population size by 72e84% and the total number of infections and deaths by 68e80%. Other studies conducted by Majumder and Mandl (2020), Riou and Althaus (2020), Liu et al. (2020), and Zhang and Wang (2020) utilized different models to estimate the reproduction number, ranging from 2.0 to 3.8. These variations in findings could be attributed to methodological differences.

The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020. Based on these estimates, the pandemics outbreak is expected to significantly decrease within 77 [95% CI 75e80] days from its beginning. Furthermore, authors found that every one-day reduction in the duration of the period from illness/symptom onset to isolation would reduce the peak population size by 72e84% and the cumulative infected cases and deaths both by 68e80%. The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Using statistical approaches, namely exponential growth and maximum likelihood techniques, Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated the value of the reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Effectively controlling and containing the coronavirus outbreak relies on a high quarantine rate of the infectious population, as shown by research by Imai et al. (2020) and Yu (2020). Yu estimated a basic reproduction number of 3.5, indicating that a quarantine rate above 90% is necessary for effective control. Kucharski et al. (2020) developed a stochastic SEIR model using the Euler-Maruyama algorithm with a 6-hour time-step and a transmission rate following a geometric Brownian motion. They estimated a time-varying reproduction number using the sequential Monte-Carlo approach and utilized multiple datasets to provide real-time estimates. The transmission process was modeled as random and fluctuating, similar to the model by Imai et al. (2020), with risks of transmission and outbreak modeled based on a negative binomial offspring distribution. The median reproduction number ranged from 1.6 to 2.9 before travel restrictions were implemented.The study by Wu and collaborators (Wu et al., 2020), based on nowcasting and forecasting approach, estimated a basic reproductive number of 2.68 (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Wuhan as of January 25th, 2020. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to
post_context: (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020.Based on the estimates provided, it is anticipated that the pandemic outbreak will decrease significantly within 77 days (95% CI 75-80) from its onset. A study by Majumder and Mandl (2020) using the IDEA model estimated a reproduction number of 2.0-3.1. Additionally, Riou and Althaus (2020) computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% HPD 1.4-3.8) using a stochastic model, while Liu et al. (2020) estimated a range of 2.90 (95% CI 2.32-3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28-3.67) using statistical approaches. Zhang and Wang (2020) inferred a time-calibrated phylogeny and found an MRCA date of December 17, 2019, with a reproduction number oscillating between 1.1 and 1.6. These varying results may be attributed to different methodological approaches, models used, datasets, and estimation periods. The fluctuation in the reproduction number over time suggests a changing dynamic in the transmission of the coronavirus outbreak and case reporting.

Furthermore, authors found that every one-day reduction in the duration of the period from illness/symptom onset to isolation would reduce the peak population size by 72e84% and the cumulative infected cases and deaths both by 68e80%. The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Using statistical approaches, namely exponential growth and maximum likelihood techniques, Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated the value of the reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). Zhang and Wang (Zhang & Wang, 2020), employing a Bayesian framework to infer time-calibrated phylogeny from 33 available genomic sequences, found that the time of the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) was December 17th, 2019 (95% highest posterior density interval from December 7th, 2019 to December 23rd, 2019) and that the value of the reproduction number oscillated between 1.1 and 1.6. These different findings may be due to several methodological issues, including different assumptions and choice of parameters, utilized models (stochastic versus deterministic, compartmental versus IDEA, etc.), used datasets and estimation period. Furthermore, by comparing the various updated versions of the above-mentioned investigations, the reproduction number was found to vary, reflecting the dynamics of transmission of the coronavirus outbreak as well as the dynamics of case reporting. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The research conducted by Mwalili et al.BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352 Page 2 of 5 non-linear  interactions  between  humans  and  the  environment;  and  (3)  thorough  simulation  studies  were performed. Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is represented as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, N(t) is equal to the sum of susceptible (S(t)), exposed (E(t)), asymptomatic infectious (IA(t)), symptomatic infectious (IS(t)), and recovered (R(t)) individuals. Research has revealed that the COVID-19 virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact as well as from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic (IA(t)) and symptomatic (IS(t)) infected individuals have been shown to spread the virus to susceptible persons (S(t)) with whom they come into contact. When infected individuals cough or sneeze without taking precautions, the virus can also spread to the environment. As the pathogen (P(t)) can survive in the environment for some time, susceptible individuals in close proximity to these environments are at risk of exposure, particularly in the early stages of the COVID-19 outbreak before hygiene measures are in place. The disease progression involves susceptible individuals moving to the exposed population (E(t)), which then transitions to either asymptomatic (IA(t)) or symptomatic (IS(t)) infectious individuals. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens present during human interactions at time t. Most infectious individuals recover and become part of the recovered population (R(t)). This interaction between the human population and the pathogens is illustrated in Figure 1, with the parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model outlined in Table 1. The model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations. Figure 1 depicts the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission, showing the interaction between humans (SEIR, yellow shade) and the pathogen (P, green shade).

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In their study, Mwalili et al. (2020) examined non-linear interactions between humans and the environment, and conducted thorough simulation studies. The researchers formulated a mathematical model to study the spread and transmission of SARS-CoV-2. The model considered two populations - humans as hosts and pathogens. The human population at time t, denoted as N(t), was divided into susceptible (S(t)), exposed (E(t)), asymptomatic infectious (IA(t)), symptomatic infectious (IS(t)), and recovered individuals (R(t)). The pathogen in the environment was denoted as P(t), resulting in the total human population being represented as N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). It was found that the virus can be transmitted through human-to-human and environment-to-human contact. Asymptomatic (IA(t)) and symptomatic (IS(t)) infected individuals were shown to spread the COVID-19 virus to susceptible individuals (S(t)) through close contact, as well as through sneezing or coughing without proper precautions, leading to virus spread in the environment.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. P(t)  is  the  number or  quantity  of  pathogens  present  during  interaction of  human  beings  at

Table 1 provides the parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model. The model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations, as shown in the SEIR-P model in Figure 1. This model represents the transmission of COVID-19 with a human compartment (SEIR) and a pathogen compartment (P).
