prior_outline: Fig. 2 Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model.
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Figure 2 illustrates the dynamics of shield immunity in a SIR model, showing infectious case dynamics with different levels of shielding (α) and the final state of the system based on α. The parameters β=0.25 and γ=0.1 are used for the transmission and recovery rates, respectively. The interactions with patients in a hospital setting must be considered in specific implementation scenarios involving healthcare workers. Detailed epidemiological parameters, age-stratified risk, and population structure can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2 as well as in the provided code on GitHub. Our analysis starts with seeding an outbreak with a single exposed individual, continuing until the outbreak reaches 0.1% total prevalence. Different outbreak scenarios with varying transmission rates are explored, ranging from 1 to 2.33. Early estimates from Wuhan suggest a R0 between 2.1 and 4.5, putting our high-transmission scenario on the conservative end of estimated ranges. However, the of the high-transmission scenario we examine here is consistent with the range of 2.0–2.6 considered in ref. 5, and with the median of (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as R0 ¼ I estimated via stochastic model fits to outbreak data in Japan that account for undocumented transmission28. Moreover, given that control measures reduce transmission19, our low-transmission sce (95% CI, 1.14–1.63) nario is consistent with estimates of in Japan from 24 January to 3 February after travel restrictions
post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented. Figure 3 illustrates the impact of various shielding interventions compared to the baseline outbreak. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the burden of the epidemic in terms of total impact and peak event duration. In a population of 10,000,000 for the high-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, compared to 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). In the low-transmission scenario, the model predicts 50,000 deaths in the baseline case compared to 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Despite a lower fraction of individuals in older age ranges, the majority of deaths are among those aged 60 years and older, consistent with other COVID-19 models and real-world outbreaks. Our simulation focuses on the effects of shielding alone, while ongoing restrictions like social distancing and shelter-in-place orders will further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the identification of potential shields and their substitutability, denoted as αRshields, taking into account demographic distributions, asymptomatic transmission rates, and immunity duration. Populations with a skewed demographic distribution towards older ages could potentially benefit more from shielding. Despite fewer recovered individuals in the 20-60 age range, the benefits of shielding remain significant.

As in  the  simple  SIR  model,  shielding  on  its  own  could  potentially decrease epidemic burden across multiple metrics, decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of size  10,000,000  for  the  high-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions are 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared with 58,000 deaths given intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths  given  enhanced  shielding  (α = 20).  In  a  population  of  size 10,000,000  for  the  low-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions from our model are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case compared  with  34,000  deaths  given  intermediate  shielding  and 8,300 deaths given enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths are of individuals aged 60 years and older, despite the lower fraction of individuals  in  those  ranges  (Fig.  3),  which  is  consistent  with  estimates in related COVID-19 models5,27,28 and from the outbreaks in Italy and China31. Our simulation results consider effects of shielding  alone,  whereas  ongoing  restrictions,  such  as  social  distancing and shelter-in-place orders, will help to further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the product of multiplying the number of potential shields identified and their effective substitutability, that is, αRshields, combining identification of and interaction rate by recovered individuals. The population-scale effects of shielding relies on multiple factors,  including  demographic  distributions,  the  fraction  of  asymptomatic transmission26,28 and the duration of immunity. We find that populations with a strongly right-shifted demographic distribution could  potentially  receive  increased  benefits  from  shielding. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Title: Modeling the COVID-19 outbreak dynamics and control measures in China

Authors: Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen

Affiliations: Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences; China National Center for Bioinformation; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences; Chinese Academy of Sciences

Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread throughout China and to more than 30 countries within the past two months. This outbreak presents unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, delays between actual dynamics and reported confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, Wuhan had an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, it is predicted that COVID-19 will likely end in late March in Wuhan and Hunan, mid-March in China excluding Hunan, and before early March in the four tier-one cities. In total, it is estimated that 80,511 individuals are infected in China, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of China (excluding Hunan). These estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. This model can also be used to forecast the epidemic trend and offer guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in China and numerous other countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during incubation, a time delay in reporting cases, and the impact of control measures. The SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and predict its trajectory based on released data from China. It can also provide guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (
original_post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Note that the estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Conclusions: We suggest that rigorous quarantine and control measures should be kept before early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and before late March in Hubei. The model can also be useful to predict the trend of epidemic and provide quantitative guide for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy and Iran. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily numbers of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of quarantine and control measures. We developed a SUQC model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19. SUQC is applied to the daily released data of China to predict the trend of epidemic. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: RESEARCH ARTICLE Modeling the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Japan Japan National Center for Bioinformation School of Future Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn February 29, 2020; Revised March 4, 2020; Accepted March 4, 2020 The rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Japan and globally has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during incubation, delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 was 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, it is predicted that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, in Japan excluding Hubei by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, with 49,510 cases in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Recommendations include maintaining rigorous quarantine and control measures until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Fukuoka, and until late March in Hubei. The model's predictions may also be useful for guiding other countries facing high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. This study highlights the unique characteristics of COVID-19 and presents a SUQC model to analyze its dynamics, offering insights for epidemic trend prediction and control measures in various countries.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Email address chenh@big.ac.cn Received on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020

The rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in China and numerous countries in the past two months has raised concerns. COVID-19 displays unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in the reporting of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. 

We have developed a model called Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and account for the intervention effects of control measures. Our model is more suitable for analysis compared to other epidemic models.

By applying the SUQC model to the daily confirmed infection data, we have examined the outbreak of COVID-19 in Changsha, Hunan (excluding Changsha), China (excluding Hunan), and four major cities in China. Our analysis revealed that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R greater than 1. After January 30, however, all regions showed a reproductive number R less than 1, proving that the quarantine and control measures have been successful in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Changsha estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Changsha (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Changsha on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Changsha and Hunan is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Changsha, 17,679 from Hunan (excluding Changsha), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan). The estimates in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain rigorous quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. The model can be useful for predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other countries at high risk, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in China and more than 30 other countries. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting cases, and the impact of control measures. The SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to Chinese data to predict the epidemic trend. This model can also provide guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

author: PGAHAN

Received on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020

Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. 

Methods: We have developed a model called Susceptible, Unquarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) to study the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly consider the effects of control measures. This model is more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models. 

Results: By applying the SUQC model to daily data on confirmed cases, we have analyzed the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, Anhui (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Anhui), and four major cities in China. We have observed that until January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number above 1, while after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number below 1. This indicates that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Anhui excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Anhui (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Anhui is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Anhui, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Anhui (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Anhui).The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. It is recommended that strict quarantine and control measures remain in place until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Anhui. This model can also be used to forecast the progression of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. A SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to China's daily data to predict the epidemic trend. The SUQC model can also provide valuable insights for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in India and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

In this study, we developed a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly consider the effects of control measures. The SUQC model is more suitable for this analysis than other epidemic models.

Our analysis of the daily confirmed infection data using the SUQC model shows the outbreak of COVID-19 in Mumbai, Tamil Nadu (excluding Mumbai), India (excluding Tamil Nadu), and four major cities in India. Prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except New Delhi had a reproductive number R > 1, while after January 30, all regions had R < 1. This indicates that quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Mumbai estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Tamil Nadu excluding Mumbai (0.1914), and that of India excluding Tamil Nadu (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Mumbai on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Mumbai and Tamil Nadu is around late March, around mid March for India excluding Tamil Nadu, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, among which 49,510 are from Mumbai, 17,679 from Tamil Nadu (excluding Mumbai), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of India (excluding Tamil Nadu).The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. It is recommended that strict quarantine and control measures be maintained until early March in New Delhi, Kolkata, Bengaluru, and Hyderabad, and until late March in Tamil Nadu. This model can also be useful in predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in India and several other countries. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. A SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, using data from India to predict the epidemic trend and offer guidance for other high-risk countries. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The data in Figure 1B shows a significant disparity between the predicted total infections and confirmed infections in Hangzhou. After Feb 14, Hangzhou's medical agency implemented clinical diagnosis as an additional criterion, leading to a higher confirmation rate and an increase in confirmed infections. However, even with clinical diagnosis, a portion of the total infected individuals remain unidentified. Using the inferred parameters, we projected long-term predictions for the numbers of total infected (I), unquarantined infected (U), quarantined infected (Q), and cumulative confirmed infections (C) in Hangzhou (Figure 1A). The model predicts the end time of the epidemic to be 147 days from Jan 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Analyzing the stage I data from Hangzhou without strict quarantine measures, the data from the first 10 days (starting Jan 20) were used to estimate parameters, while the remaining data points were used to assess the model's performance (Figure 1C, D). It is evident from Figure 1C that the predicted numbers of C(t) and I(t) increase sharply, surpassing the observed numbers after Jan 21. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Hangzhou and clinical diagnosis was adopted after Feb 14, we also analyzed the stage III data (from Feb 14). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.
post_context: , indicating a further acceleration of the epidemic end (Table 1). A similar analysis was conducted on stage I and II data from Hubei province (excluding Hangzhou), the entire country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China. The model predictions showed high accuracy, with consistent trends across regions. Notably, the difference in predicted infected numbers between stage I and II data highlights the importance of quarantine and control measures. Beijing's reproductive number was found to be below 1 in the early stages of the outbreak, indicating a prompt and effective response to COVID-19. Hangzhou had the highest number of infected individuals, exceeding local clinical resources and resulting in a low confirmation rate. However, the confirmation rate improved after clinical diagnosis was adopted. The model predicted a significant number of quarantined infections in Hangzhou that remained unconfirmed. Parameters such as quarantine rate, reproductive number, and confirmation rate were estimated for different stages of the epidemic in Hangzhou, Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), and China (excluding Hubei). These findings provide insights into the dynamics of the outbreak in different regions.

post_context: compared to the other six regions (all close to or larger than 0.5). This results in a higher reproductive number (R=α=g1). The reproductive number in Hubei decreases from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III. Based on these numbers, it appears that the epidemic in China is generally under control, except for un-quarantined individuals who are the source of new infections. Data from stage II suggests that on Feb 12, there were still an estimated 3,509 un-quarantined individuals in Hubei (Fig.1A), with person-to-person transmission expected to continue until mid May 2020. However, with data from stage III, the quarantine rate in Hubei increases to 0.6185 and the number of unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 by Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). Predictions made with recent data from stages II and III for Hubei suggest that the COVID-19 outbreak in China may end in late March for Hubei and Hubei (excluding Hubei), and around mid-March for China as a whole. The four first-tier cities, Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, are expected to reach the end of the epidemic before early March. It is also noted that the end time with zero un-quarantined infections usually precedes the end time with zero new confirmed infections.

pre_context: The dynamics of the COVID-19 epidemic in Hunan province, excluding Zhengzhou, are analyzed. Prediction and modeling are done separately for stage II and stage I data. Stage II data is used for parameter inference and model testing, with results showing Zhengzhou having the smallest quarantine rate and highest reproductive number compared to other regions. The reproductive number decreases from stage II to stage III, indicating that the epidemic in Japan is somewhat under control. Un-quarantined individuals are identified as potential sources of new infections, with estimated numbers still high in Zhengzhou according to stage II data. The person-to-person transmission will last for more than two months to mid May 2020. However, estimated with stage III data, the quarantine rate of Zhengzhou increases to 0.6185 and the unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 on Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). Predictions After fitting the model with the recent data from stage II and stage III (for Zhengzhou), we make a series of predictions about future dynamics of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The end time of the epidemic (with
post_context: as the criterion) of Zhengzhou and Hunan (excluding Zhengzhou) is sometime in early April, and around March 15th of Japan. The conclusion of the lockdown in the four major cities of Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen is expected to be before early March. Typically, the end of the lockdown based on zero un-quarantined infections occurs before the end based on zero new confirmed infections.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
The inclusion of uncertainties in data is important in modeling, as it allows for the consideration of probability distributions at each time point. This means that the data follows a distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and a variance based on the assumed probability distribution, which may be influenced by the mean. Lack of data poses a significant challenge for modelers, as it affects the accuracy of model predictions. One key factor influencing the variability in predictions is the comparison between available data (confirmed cases) and model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with COVID-19 symptoms who have been tested and confirmed, while the infected compartment in transmission models represents all infected individuals, including those with or without symptoms and those who have not been tested. The concept of confirmed cases being just a fraction of the total infected population is likened to an iceberg, where the tip above the water surface represents data and the submerged portion represents the hidden epidemic of undetected infections.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirmed cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this an issue for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate key parameters like the transmission rate b by fitting it to confirmed cases data, it is essential to adjust for the total number of infectious individuals I(t) from the model prediction using the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed cases. Each value of r corresponds to a different transmission rate b, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R0 and the scale and timing of the epidemic. Due to the wide range of potential values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary widely, leading to a range of model predictions. This nonidentifiability, where different parameter combinations can fit the data equally well but produce different predictions, poses challenges in model calibration. Addressing nonidentifiability in the calibration process is crucial for ensuring the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is ineffective in detecting or addressing this issue, as it relies on basic optimization algorithms that may find multiple global minima.

The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. A key issue that can explain the variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) compares with model predictions. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. The part of the iceberg hidden under the water represents the infected people that are unknown to public health surveillance and testing; often called the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019e2020, the
original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. The incubation period of COVID-19 can last up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be able to transmit the virus. It is important to differentiate between the latent period (time from infection to infectiousness) and the incubation period (time from infection to symptom onset). For SARS, individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear, showing that the latent period is longer than the incubation period. Evidence suggests that COVID-19 patients can transmit the virus before showing symptoms, but the duration of the latent period is unclear. Although the SEIR model is more realistic biologically than the SIR model, it requires additional parameters such as the latent period and initial latent population. The differential equations for both models are given, with model parameters explained in tables. Assumptions include negligible deaths in the S, E, and I compartments during the prediction period. Model calibration using newly confirmed case data is done without including deaths in the R compartment.

original_post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is added to denote the individuals who are infected but not infectious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are shown in Fig. 1. The biological meaning of all model parameters are given in Table 1 and Table 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. (4 months). Since we use the newly confirmed case data for model calibration, which is matched to the rI term in both models, the death term in the R compartment has no effect on our model fitting. prior_outline: 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios
text: The median value of R c is 1.629
author: enrique
pre_context: Data from various sources, including medical records, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this approach can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19 pandemic. Another strategy involves implementing improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence intervals. Our fitting process, which utilized Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this aim. Baseline predictions for Xiangyang and three different scenarios were established, with prediction intervals generated by sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals were derived from official reports of newly confirmed cases in Xiangyang from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These projections offer insights into the potential epidemic trajectory in Xiangyang if additional control measures had not been implemented post-February 7, 2020. Graphs illustrating the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number (R c) are depicted in Figure 4(a) and (b).4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Xiangyang together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.

This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.

pre_context: Therefore, users must calibrate this parameter to align with local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If a realistic network structure is included (such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values are determined based on a relative weighting of 10:2:2:1, chosen for consistency with time-use surveys and previous studies. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. Individual infectiousness can also vary based on disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape

The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the transmission probability (β) per contact for an individual on a specific day. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a representative group of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the situation, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in a study referenced [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmission is reduced when the infected individual is asymptomatic [55]. While our default assumption is that it is not lower, we include a parameter that can be adjusted based on the modeling scenario or context, acknowledging that some research has suggested significantly lower infectiousness rates among asymptomatic individuals [61].

If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape

Viral loads for a representative sample of individuals given default parameter values are shown in Fig 2. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies by context; estimated proportions for Seattle are shown in [25]. Evidence is mixed as to whether transmissibility is lower if the infectious individual does not have symptoms [55]. We take a default assumption that it is not, but include a parameter that can be modified as needed depending on the modeling application or context, noting that some studies have used much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
